title: The Swan's Way Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Andy Gryce / View from road between Eythrope and Stone 2
images.caption: View from road between Eythrope and Stone. This view to the south-east from about 1.5km along the private road from Stone to Eythrope Park, is of the northern edge of a wood, The Nursery, with Starveall Farm in the middle distance to the right. The private road is a bridleway and is on the route of the Midshire's Way and Swan's Way.

images.title: Swan's Way by Christmas Gorse by Philip Jeffrey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Swan's Way by Christmas Gorse

images.title: Swan's Way on the top of Quainton Hill by Philip Jeffrey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Swan's Way on the top of Quainton Hill

images.title: Andy Gryce / Houses, Eythrope Road
images.caption: Houses, Eythrope Road. These houses are on the edge of the village of Stone from where the road is coming. At this point, behind the camera, the road becomes a private road to Eythrope Park though it is a bridleway and is on the route of the Midshire's Way and Swan's Way.

images.title: David Hawgood / Bridleway to Eythrope Park
images.caption: Bridleway to Eythrope Park

images.title: Andrew Smith / Farmland, South Stoke
images.caption: Farmland, South Stoke. Looking down from the Swan's Way to the west of Watch Folly. The grassy strips are the runways of the Chiltern Park Aerodrome.

description: The Swan's Way long distance bridleroute runs from Salcey Forest in the north to Goring on Thames in the south, a distance of 65 miles (105km). From the Northants border, the route crosses the Vale of Aylesbury to meet the Ridgeway near Princes Risborough and then follows the chalk slopes of the Chilterns to the Thames at Goring. It passes through varied countryside from beech woods on chalk scarp to low vales and ancient woodlands. This route was submitted by Mark Worthington.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: In Lewknor there's The Leathern Bottle for a pit stop on the trail. It's an historic pub of some note dating all the way back to the 1600s. The Grade II listed pub serves good quality food and includes a splendid large garden area to relax in on warm summer days. They have a large car park so the pub makes a good start point for a walk in the area.

display_address: Hartwell, West Northamptonshire, England, NN7 2HA, United Kingdom
